user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_NetworkGetHostName_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_NetworkGetHostName_Impl(char *host_name, size_t name_len)
{
    int32 return_code;

    if (gethostname(host_name, name_len) < 0)
    {
        return_code = OS_ERROR;
    }
    else
    {
        /*
         * posix does not say that the name is always
         * null terminated, so its worthwhile to ensure it
         */
        host_name[name_len - 1] = 0;
        return_code             = OS_SUCCESS;
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function OS_NetworkGetHostName_Impl:
#define OS_ERROR (-1)
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
...
int32 OS_NetworkGetHostName(char *host_name, size_t name_len)
{
    int32 return_code;

    /* Check parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(host_name);
    OS_CHECK_SIZE(name_len);

    /* delegate to low-level API */
    return_code = OS_NetworkGetHostName_Impl(host_name, name_len);
    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        /* return an empty string on failure, just in case */
        host_name[0] = 0;
    }

    return return_code;
}
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
OS_CHECK_POINTER(host_name);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 2.1 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: The fragment itself does not necessarily create unreachable code. A violation would occur if the OS_CHECK_POINTER macro unconditionally transfers control (for example, expands to a return, longjmp, or infinite loop), making the subsequent statements in the function unreachable. Example violating expansion: #define OS_CHECK_POINTER(p) do { if ((p) == NULL) { return OS_INVALID_POINTER; } } while (0) — this makes the rest of the function unreachable when the macro always returns for some inputs and thus can produce unreachable code paths. If the macro expands only to a check that does not unconditionally transfer control (e.g. a null-check that sets an error code or a void-cast), then Rule 2.1 is not violated.
